bestBHT.bht: As the disciples gathered, prompted by Peter, John questioned on behalf of all, Is it I, Lord? Jesus' response, Thou hast said, confirmed that one among them would indeed carry out this treacherous act. The disciples, excluding Judas, asked sincerely, filled with sorrow and uncertainty as to who the betrayer could be. They sought to distance themselves from any suspicion, abhorring the very thought of such an iniquitous deed.

Henry Alford: The real enquiry from the Lord was made by John himself, owing to a sign from Peter.
This part of John's narrative stands in the highest position for accuracy of detail.
The facts related in it are evidently the ground of the other accounts.
Marvin Vincent: Began to say...one after the other (every one) saying, 'Is it I?'"
The form of the negative expects a negative answer."
John Calvin: I do not think that the disciples were alarmed, as persons struck with terror are wont to give themselves uneasiness without any reason.
It is, indeed, a mark of reverence, that when indirectly blamed, they do not reply angrily to their Master, but each person constitutes himself his own judge.
Relying on a good conscience, they wish to declare frankly how far they are from meditating such a crime.
Philip Schaff: Is it I, Lord? Comp, the fuller details in John 13:18-30."
The Greek form of this question implies a denial; hence the hypocrisy of Judas in asking the question by himself, after the others."
Yet every Christian may ask such a question at the Lord’s table.
Archibald T. Robertson: The negative expects the answer No and was natural for all save Judas.
But he had to bluff it out by the same form of question.
The answer of Jesus, Thou hast said, means Yes.
John Gill: And they were exceeding sorrowful... and greatly, because they knew not, nor could not conceive, who of them could be guilty of such an horrid sin.

This they said, though conscious to themselves the thing had never entered into their hearts; nor had they taken any step towards it, but with their whole souls abhorred it; yet, as knowing the treachery and deceitfulness, of their hearts, which they could not trust to.

And fearing lest should they be left thereunto, they might commit such a dreadful iniquity; and as desirous of being cleared by Christ from any such imputation, and even from all suspicion of anything of this kind.

bhtAttempts.bht: As the disciples gathered together, they could not help but ask, Is it I, Lord? Each one, prompted by John, questioned their own hearts, fearing that they might be the one to betray Jesus. The form of the negative in their question expected a negative answer, each person exclaiming, Surely I am not the one. Yet, even Judas, the one who would ultimately betray Jesus, had to mask his guilt by asking the same question. In response to their inquiries, Jesus simply replied, Thou hast said, affirming that indeed, one among them would fulfill this treacherous act. This moment stands as a testament to the disciples' reverence and their desire to distance themselves from such a crime, showing their sorrowful hearts as they grappled with the unknown identity of the betrayer.

As the disciples gathered together, John inquired on behalf of the rest, Is it I, Lord? In response to their inquiries, Jesus affirmed, Thou hast said. The disciples, excluding Judas, asked this question out of reverence and a desire to distance themselves from such a treacherous act. They were filled with sorrow, not knowing the identity of the betrayer but fearing that they might be implicated. It was a reflection of their innocence, as they abhorred any thought of such a crime and sought to be cleared of any suspicion.

As the disciples gathered together, John, prompted by Peter, asked on behalf of all, Is it I, Lord? Their question, seeking denial, showed their reverence and desire to distance themselves from betrayal. Jesus' response, Thou hast said, confirmed that amongst them, one would fulfill this treacherous act. The disciples, excluding Judas, asked sincerely, for they were filled with sorrow and did not know the identity of the betrayer. They longed to be cleared of any suspicion and distance themselves from such an abhorrent crime.

As the disciples gathered, prompted by Peter, John questioned on behalf of all, Is it I, Lord? Their earnest query reflected their reverence and their desire to distance themselves from betraying Jesus. Jesus' response, Thou hast said, confirmed that one among them would indeed carry out this treacherous act. The disciples, excluding Judas, asked sincerely, filled with sorrow and uncertainty as to who the betrayer could be. They sought to be cleared of suspicion, abhorring the mere thought of such an iniquitous deed.

As the disciples gathered, prompted by Peter, John questioned on behalf of all, Is it I, Lord? Jesus' response, Thou hast said, confirmed that one among them would indeed carry out this treacherous act. The disciples, excluding Judas, asked sincerely, filled with sorrow and uncertainty as to who the betrayer could be. They sought to distance themselves from any suspicion, abhorring the very thought of such an iniquitous deed.
